texts.shortText:
Medium-sized dolphin with snout abruptly narrower that head (hence ‘bottlenosed’). Dorsal fin relatively large and strongly curved backwards. Teeth only 22–29 in each jaw and unusually stout and conical.

Body colour plain and shading from dark gray dorsally to white along the belly. Belly often freckled with dark spots.
Medium-sized, with a maximum length of 2.4 m and mass of 230 kg. Males marginally larger than females, but differences barely detectable.

Global: Widely distributed in Indo-Pacific from south and east coasts of Africa to Red Sea, India, China and northern Australia.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique. Not on west coast.

Usually occur fairly close inshore in groups that vary widely in size from 1–1000 (averaging 40 in one study from the Eastern Cape and 140 in another). Mainly active in the morning and less so in the evening and commonly seen surfing in the breakers. May be predated on by sharks and are subject to mortality by capture in bather protection nets in KwaZulu-Natal.  Also accumulate chlorinated hydrocarbons in the blubber with age and these are ‘offloaded’ by females to the young in their milk, with unknown effects. Longevity has been estimated at 42–43 years in both sexes.
Feeds on a wide variety of both fish and cephalopods with 72 different prey species found in a sample of 165 animals caught in the bather-protection nets off KwaZulu-Natal.

Males reach sexual maturity at an age of about 14 years and females at 9–11 years, usually producing their first calf at an age of 12–15.  Gestation period is about 12 months and along the KwaZulu-Natal coast most births take place in summer and autumn. Calves are born at a length of about 100 cm and mass of 9–21 kg and are weaned at an age of 1.5–2 years (but this may vary widely between regional populations).

The taxonomy of Bottlenose dolphins has been confused and earlier accounts do not distinguish between this species and the very similar Common bottlenose dolphin Tursiops truncatus, so earlier descriptions of distribution and biology may refer to either species. The Common bottlenose dolphin is somewhat larger in size (3.3 m) and tends to occur further offshore. Anatomically it has fewer teeth on each jaw (21–24), a shorter beak and a brighter colour pattern, usually with a light grey blaze that runs from side of the head to below the dorsal fin. The sides of the belly are also not spotted, as in adult Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins.

Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 100).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 181).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 366).

Cockcroft, V & Joyce, P (1998). Whale Watch: A Guide to Whales and other Marine Mammals of Southern Africa. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 90 does not distinguish the 2 species).
